newsitem.title: USA: IBM, Cascade plan mainframe connections.
newsitem.headline: IBM, Cascade plan mainframe connections.

text.p: International Business Machines Corp and Cascade Communications Corp said they expanded their strategic alliance to include development of direct connections between IBM mainframes and the Internet.

The two companies said that providing direct connections between S/390 mainframe machines and the Internet, intranet and Wide Area Networks (WANs) will result in significantly reduced demand for intermediate network gateway products.
The latest agreement by Cascade and IBM's mainframe unit extends an earlier pact announced in March that joined Cascade and IBM's network unit in a product development alliance.
The project focuses on machines known as System/390 Parallel Enterprise Servers, the latest generation of IBM mainframes.
The result of the joint technology project will be to provide faster, less expensive network access for IBM mainframe software and data, the two companies said.
A spokeswoman said the project would create connections using a mix of Cascade and IBM switching equipment.
"We are taking the next step in the ongoing relationship between IBM and Cascade," said Deborah Miller, an IBM spokeswoman.
"The majority of the world's data is housed in S/390 servers," said Desh Deshpande, executive vice president and founder of Cascade, in a statement.
"This development effort between Cascade and IBM will make that data even more readily available throughout the Internet," he said.

Currently, organizations using mainframe computers to connect to the Internet must route S/390 data through a variety of intermediate gateways. IBM and Cascade said they will write new software code designed to bypass gateways using methods that are transparent to customers using the computers.

IBM and Cascade said their planned S/390 connection will be compatible with a variety of key Internet technologies, including the TCP/IP Internet protocol, Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) and frame relay, two high speed-switching technologies that handle multimedia voice video and data.

The mainframe connnections will also work with Switched Multi-Megabit Data Service (SMDS) and Integrated Switched Digital Network systems, two additional high-speed network transmission technologies, they said.
Such a project could reduce demand for network router and switching equipment supplied by companies such as Cisco Systems Inc and other network equipment suppliers.

The IBM-Cascade plan comes shortly after Cisco annnounced it will extend its core Internetworking Operating System to integrate with IBM mainframes and midrange computers running on corporate internal networks, or intranets.
The plan, announced December 13, involved Cisco taking a minority stake in mainframe software developer Interlink Computer Sciences Inc.
